I.</br>Daughter of Ate, pow'r accurst!</br>Whose right hand waves a bloody rod,</br>Whom bigot Rage and Frenzy nurst,</br>And bow'd thee to a tyrant's nod:</br>Sullen Goddess!  at whose shrine</br>Oft' the innocent have bled,</br>Oft' the sons of freedom's line</br>Have sunk amongst the dead;</br>Where'er amidst the cloister'd gloom,</br>And shades of ignominious Rome,</br>Perplex'd in Error's mazes blind,</br>Thy devious footsteps ling'ring stray;</br>Grim-visag'd Horror stalks behind,</br>And Murder marks his way.

II.</br>Indulg'd by thee in southern climes</br>What deeds of darkness have been done:</br>Secret treasons, horrid crimes,</br>Which ne'er beheld the sun;</br>Moon-struck Madness, frantic Fear,</br>Follow, follow, in thy train,</br>Despair, that drops an iron tear,</br>And Anguish wild that knaws his chain:</br>The wretch who flies to thee for aid,</br>When Death's dread shafts his soul invade,</br>Shall find thou hast no pow'r to save,</br>Aghast, he views th' eternal shore,</br>Sighs for the refuge of the grave,</br>And sinks, to rise no more.

III.</br>Ha!  see amid yon deep'ning gloom</br>What forms in long procession rise,</br>Ascending from the yawning tomb,</br>And upwards hast'ning to the skies.</br>Heard you not how firm they stood,</br>And all the tyrant's rage defy'd,</br>How they steep'd their robes in blood,</br>How they triumph'd, how they died?</br>Victorious over Death and Time,</br>In ev'ry distant age and clime,</br>Their names shall live, to Mem'ry dear,</br>For ever fair their virtues bloom;</br>And oft' with many an holy tear,</br>Sweet Pity dew their tomb.

IV.</br>But lo!  on Britain's sea-girt shore,</br>What woes her wretched sons await,</br>What dire events portentous low'r,</br>Big with impending fate;</br>O'er the nobles of the land,</br>O'er mighty James's royal head,</br>Unknown, unseen, some wizard hand,</br>The woof of destiny has spread;</br>Where is the sun's all chearing light?</br>His golden orb is lost in night;</br>Swift pace the night-steed to their goal,</br>Dim thro' the dusk the stars appear,</br>Horror seizes on the soul,</br>And spirit-quenching Fear.

V.</br>Hell from beneath hath heard a sound,</br>Loudly thrice, and thrice it call'd,</br>Her shaggy caverns trembled round,</br>The King of terrors heard appall'd;</br>'Tis done, 'tis done, a fury cry'd,</br>As faintly flash'd the lightning's gleam,</br>The cell, the nit'rous grain I spy'd,</br>I snuff'd the sulphur's murky steam:</br>Back thro' all th' infernal bound,</br>Hell reverb'rated the sound;</br>Dire Expectation then was seen</br>Along the infernal coast,</br>With haggard look, and frantic mien,</br>To glide — a pensive ghost!

VI.</br>'Tis o'er, the hour of darkness dread,</br>Sudden the frowning tempest past;</br>As o'er yon distant mountain's head</br>The light cloud flies before the blast;</br>Britain's guardian pow'r shall shield</br>The fav'rite isle that owns her aid,</br>Attend her heroes to the field,</br>And save from harms when foes invade:</br>But haste thee, Superstition, far</br>Where Slaughter rolls his rapid car,</br>Amongst the dying and the dead;</br>Or 'midst some howling desart dwell,</br>Or with the furies make thy bed,</br>And meditate thy spell.

VII.</br>Britain's guardian, pow'r benign!</br>Still on her rocks thy station keep,</br>To guard her sea-girt isle be thine,</br>To roll her thunders o'er the deep:</br>Nor thou, fair Piety, disdain</br>In heav'n-born Freedom's seat to dwell,</br>With Virtue, native of the plain,</br>With Science in her letter'd cell;</br>While Truth reflects your beams combin'd</br>On the clear mirror of the mind—</br>And often to your hallow'd shrine</br>The muse some votive gift shall bring,</br>And Fancy, nymph of birth divine,</br>Around your altars sing.</br>
